Authors: Molly R Letsch, Louise A Lewis
Title:
Four Gene Arrangements Within the Chloroplast Genome of a
Closely Related Group of Green Algae (Trebouxiophyceae,
Chlorophyta)
Keywords: Gene order, Embryophyte, rbcL, SSU rDNA
Abstract:
The chloroplast genomes of green algae (Chlorophyta)
published to date each possess a unique gene arrangement. The 18
published green algal chloroplast genomes include only a few
representatives from each diverse and phylogenetically widespread
lineage in Chlorophyta, lineages have been diverging from one another
for >1000 million years. In order to understand more about the
variability of chloroplast gene arrangements at a more shallow
phylogenetic scale, we compared the order of genes in a 1.5-4 kb segment
of the chloroplast genome among 18 isolates representing nine species in
three genera of closely related trebouxiophyte green algae. In all, four
different gene arrangements of this chloroplast segment were determined
across Elliptochloris, Hemichloris, and Coccomyxa. In one genus,
Elliptochloris, we detected three distinct chloroplast gene
arrangements, one of which is shared with members of its sister genus
Hemichloris. In both species of Coccomyxa, this chloroplast genome
segment was characterized by very long spacer regions. The extent of
gene order rearrangement found in this small segment of the chloroplast
genome among three closely related genera of green algae is in stark
contrast with the conserved gene order seen in embryophyte (land plant)
genera. Given that taxonomic ranks are not equivalent among different
groups of organisms, the maximum molecular divergence among taxa sharing
a common gene arrangement also was compared. Within well-supported
monophyletic groups with single gene arrangements, embryophyte and green
algal clades were found to have similar phylogenetic depth. When the
dominant gene arrangement in embryophytes was assumed to be ancestral
for all of the embryophytes, the maximum molecular divergence was found
to be over two times greater in embryophytes than in the trebouxiophyte
green algae examined in this study, further illustrating fluidity of
green algal chloroplast architecture in comparison to the relative
conservation of embryophyte chloroplast genomes.
